column3: This is a housing and mixed use project that uses an existing on grade parking lot owned and operated by the City of Santa Barbara.  Central to the concept is the use of a fully automated robotic parking garage to replace existing parking and provide additional parking for the proposed housing.  Additionally, the redevelopment of a portion of State street with mixed use housing and a paseo that cuts through to State Street from the open space proposed for the transit plaza. The number of units proposed is between 200 and 400 depending on the type and size of unit.

column2: Luna Y Dos Soles (Transit Plaza and Figueroa/Anacapa Blocks)
column3:
Together, these two blocks not only provide downtown housing but provide a sense of arrival for bus passengers and revitalize the transit center with integrated bus, bicycle and ride share options.  A network of paseos, walkways, open space and parks is created, and fosters interaction with casual entertainment and food options.  The buildings use sustainable design and take advantage of subterranean parking.

The Luna Block (Chapala Transit Plaza) provides an opportunity as a gateway to the downtown State Street promenade.  The crescent-shaped turn-in off Chapala Street for the buses provides the inspiration for new curved and tiered buildings overlooking the park as well as the name of the project.  It provides 10 off-street bus parking spaces, 135 housing units on upper floors, a revamped transit center office, neighborhood grocery store, commercial/art gallery space on the first floor and subterranean parking below grade.   A park in the center of the block is looped by a pedestrian walkway with bollards that can be removed for temporary service vehicles.  Removing one storefront on State Street creates a direct pedestrian path through the site to the Transit Center.  While State Street's facade is largely maintained for its unique characteristics, more housing units were added behind the existing structures overlooking the new park.

The Dos Soles Block (Figueroa and Anacapa Block) provides an opportunity as a passageway to Santa Barbara Court House.  The block is currently occupied by banks and commercial buildings, many of which are historically significant.  The corner of Figueroa and Anacapa is remade with a 4-story mixed use building,  86 housing units on upper floors and subterranean parking below grade.  Surface parking in the middle of the block is replaced with a food truck oriented park in the center for people-watching, live music and open space during lunch and dinner hours.

column16: Please note that the Dos Soles Block parcel size is 42,120 square feet.  It has a 54 foot high building with two 65-foot towers.  It provides 86 new housing units at a density of 89 units/acre.  The average unit size is 789 square feet.  It is 4 stories tall with a ground floor of commercial/bank space with 3 stories of residential above.  The gross building floor area is 92,440 square feet and the gross building FAR is 2.2.

column3:
400 Block Goals: 

 

The goal of the 400 Block is to create a vibrant and green space for residents and visitors alike. To provide commercial and residential mixed use, while preserving its historical landmarks and making room for innovations and art of the future. The main challenges faced in this block are the lack of residential space, access to open spaces, pedestrian safety, and dynamic commercial uses. To change this, our team re imagined the 400 block with the following changes: 

 

1.    Closure of State Street in the 400 Block for all non- emergency vehicles. 

2.    Conversion and preservation of the Historic Savoy Theater for residential use.

3.    Green Roofs/ Terrace and courtyards for addition of open space. 

4.    Paseos and alleyways connecting the courtyards through State Street to Haley, Chapala, Anacapa and Gutierrez.  

5.    Redevelopment of the 99 Only Store and the adjacent surface parking lots into housing.

6.    Addition of housing above existing commercial buildings along State, Anacapa and Chapala.

column2: The State Street Foundation: Why Don't We Do It In The Road?
column3:
The State Street Foundation is a public-private partnership which creates, funds and implements phased projects based on a master plan. Activities are programmed in partnership with Santa Barbara businesses, institutions and non-profits. State Street reinvigoration, reinvention, reimagination and repurposing receives continuous support via a dedicated non-profit organization for the benefit
of our community. A linear park is home to extensive programmed events. The park begins at the waterfront and ends at Micheltorena Street and includes seven East-West pedestrain extensions which integrate special districts and cultural landmarks. It is supported by a one way transportation loop of shuttle, transit and bike lanes.

column3:
We feel the best bet for creating long term economic and cultural sustainability downtown, has as much to do with redefining the commercial use of this area as it does with adding more housing units. Although it is critically important to resolve our housing crisis, in order to successfully prepare for the unknown challenges we will face in next 20, 50 or 100 years, we must also develop the means to support and sustain livelihoods at the local level.
Our solution is to offer an experience more deeply engaged in process and product. Affordable housing is only one half of the equation. Santa Barbara must also invest in the type of workforce that the community wants to be part of. Housing and livelihood must go hand in hand. To address this need, we propose turning the 500 block into an area dedicated to cohesive community growth - ultimately becoming a resilient and productive live/work environment.

To achieve this, we need to ensure that the right mixture of uses will get developed; ones capable of providing an even driving force for both economic and cultural stability. Examples are:

-Workforce housing

-Digital fabrication & software engineering

-Light manufacturing

-Daycare

-Food production commissary kitchen

-Art residence program

column2: Makers' Block (500) - Team B - SITE & LANDSCAPE PLAN
column3: Increased housing downtown means we also have to provide plenty of new open and public spaces. This calls for innovation. The future of downtown depends on rethinking our open spaces in order to capture all the valuable synergies that come from combining residential, commercial and public activities into a single, interdependent city-scape.

column2: Makers' Block (500) - Team B - THE KEEP BUILDING
column3: The Keep is mixed-use multi-family development at the corner of Anacapa and Haley St. The ‘U’ shaped development provides a continuous street front and opens into a central courtyard. A garage podium with stacked parking is provided within the wrapped building mass, shielding it from the street front. This flexible space can be converted into an event space as parking demand decreases over time. A private elevated garden is located above the parking podium. At the ground floor, the commercial storefronts create an activated ground plane that leads into the State St. Parkway. The upper 3 stories contain a diverse mix of residential unit sizes, arranged along a double loaded corridor.
column8: Density regulations, Affordable housing, Parking requirements, Alternate Open Yard

column2: Makers' Block (500) - Team B - THE CHANGE BUILDING
column3: Partially crouched on top of the back half of the 8-18 E. Cota Street building, this adaptive reuse also involves demolishing the building directly behind it, and replacing it with a 5 story multi-family building. The ground-up portion - facing the Central Court - consists of (48) 300 sqft micro-units above 3,500 sqft of commercial tenant space. The addition atop the Cota building consists of (10) 180 sqft single-room-occupancy (SRO) units that rely on a communal kitchen and shared bathrooms. This would provide room and board for students, artists or even young workers/apprentices employed below, or somewhere close by.
